data.title: A little disappointed
data.text: I was super excited to go here, so many good reviews. They don't have a full bar. Their wait staff was not helpful and their food was just OK.  Not planning on going back

data.title: Extremely friendly, service minded, and ono, too!
data.text: We felt right at home in this casual, Hawaiian family plate lunch heaven.  Lots of great authentic island choices.  We chose the classic spam musubi, crispy Mochiko chicken, moist lau lau, and saimen bowl.  The plates come with rice and dreamy creamy house-made macaroni salad.  Wish we had saved room for dessert; they looked delicious, so we'll have to go again!  NOTE: No longer in Everett, but Lynnwood address is 14626 Hwy. 99, Suite 101.  Don't let the strip mall location deter you from tasty treats.

data.title: Good thing that Hawaiian BBQ joints are few.
data.text:
Lots of pros and cons with this place. It's an actual family style restaurant where you get seated and waited on versus every other Hawaiian place I've been where you order at a counter and then pick up your food when it's ready so that was nice. The space is large but comfortable and has a tv in case there is a Seahawks game on like it was when I visited but you can't see it from everywhere and there is only 1 so keep that in mind. 

Whenever I visit a Hawaiian restaurant for the first time, I always order the Kalua Pork with cabbage. It's a staple of Hawaiian cuisine and fortunately or unfortunately depending on how you see it, it's like pizza. Even if it's bad, it's still pretty good. If I go back a second time, I'll order a Lau Lau plate but I noticed that on Bobby's menu, it describes their Lau Lau plate as pork wrapped in fig leaves. True Lau Lau as you might know is butterfish, not pork so I don't think I'll be back to order that. One thing about Hawaiian restaurants is that they are few and far between so unless you want to travel, you're kinda stuck going to the closest place to your home. At least with Bobby's, that's not a completely horrible thing. 

Some of might complaints are they only give you a fork and one napkin. Hawaiian food can get messy so having multiple napkins would be nice and at the end of my meal when my plate was nearly clean, it would have been nice to have a knife or a spoon even to help me get those pesky remnants on to my fork. I had an order of the Lumpia and it was good but I would have liked to have more sweet chili sauce to dip them in. Their teriyaki sauce was tasty but refrigerated so I quickly dropped the temperature of my food while applying the sauce to it and halfway through my meal, I was asked if I was done with it so that they could give it to another table to use. I was okay with it but I'd really like to see them have enough bottles so that each table could have their own.

They offer a few mixed drinks and they have a nice selection of beer in bottles plus wine if you'd rather. Overall I wasn't disappointed and I will definitely be back when I'm in the Lynnwood area. 

Pro tip: The Everett location is closed. The Lynwood location is the only location but your GPS may tell you otherwise.

Thanks for reading.

data.title: Hard to spot off hwy 99
data.text: I love Loco Moco, and this establishment does it very well. The burger patties are hand made every morning, not frozen like so many other spots that do this meal. The gravy was savory. The décor is a little sparse but reflects it's Hawaiian heritage in decorations.

data.title: Home Cooking, Hawaiian-Style
data.text: This family run restaurant offers home-style Hawaiian food.  Likely mom, daughter or a relative will be your server.  This is a plate-lunch (or dinner) place like you'd find in Hawaii.  I'm concerned that some reviews appear to think this should be a classy or wildly pretentious restaurant; it's not, it's a casual Hawaiian plate lunch spot in a bit nicer building than most.  Good fried Ahi (tuna), chicken katsu and Hawaiian teri-chicken.  (Don't miss the teri-chicken burger with fries.)  I've enjoyed their Lau-Lau, but ask when it was made as it is best when it is very fresh.  Decent fried rice, but remember it is Hawaiian style, so nothing in it except a few slices of green onion. If it's busy, service is a little slow, but that's Hawaiian style, too...so just relax and listen to the Hawaiian music or talk-story your lunch/dinner partners if service is a little slow.  Take out available.  Remember, it is not in Everett any longer as they relocated to Lynnwood.

data.title: Ono family cooking - New location in Lynnwood
data.text: Kalbi ribs were perfectly cooked with a good grilled flavor, not too salty.  The mochiko chicken was crispy on the outside, but juicy and tender.  Everyone in our party had a different combo and all was ono, just like back "home".  Service was fine, so I am not sure what was going on with the other reviewers. Parking was easy too.   One disappointment was the mac salad.  It was watery with overcooked pasta, so a loss of a star for a Hawaiian  plate staple.   The restaurant is not fancy, but does great home cooking.  It was a drive for us, but we will be heading back again and again.

data.title: Too many customers for them to handle.
data.text: We use to eat at Booby's when they were in downtown Everett.  Since they have moved to south Everett the slow service that they use to offer has gone to none existent service.  The only person working every time that we eat there is the owner's daughter.  She moves at a snail's pace regardless of the number of customers in the restaurant.  She cannot handle more than 3 tables of customers at a time w/out getting lost.  The last time we stopped there to eat we waited 20 minutes before deciding that she was too busy for any more customers.  The customer that she was waiting on when we walked in the door was receiving their food and she had yet to take our order.  Good food but not worth the poor service that you have to endure to get it.

data.title: BEWARE- Hazardous Red, Raw pork
data.text: WORST catering experience ever. Diane is untruthful and rude. Food was one hour ten minutes late. Diane blamed it on heavy traffic in an area that there is no such road ( as she described to me on the telephone explaining why she was late.) Diane shows up, sets food on counter, gets paid  and then leaves in a huff. She forgot that we also paid for a "full menu"---meaning plates, plastic ware, napkins, table cloths, etc.  When I went outside to talk to her about this, she sped out of the driveway- of course---because she was paid. The tray of shredded pork she dropped off, was cool/warm with much of the pork still red, raw and cold to the touch. Diane calls my cellular phone the day after to vent and complain to me about the poor review that she received from my experience. What did she expect? Lousy customer service. Hazardous food conditions and a complete waste of time and money.

data.title: Great Hawaiian home cooking
data.text: Don't come to Bobby's expecting gourmet food. It's not gourmet. It's not fancy. It IS, however, excellent Hawaiian-style home cooking, and for a great price. You definitely won't go home hungry from Bobby's! The portions are ample, Hawaiian comfort food at its best. Yes, the mac salad and white rice are on the bland side, but for those familiar with Hawaiian cooking, that's the way they're supposed to be. If you want something popping with exciting or spicy flavor, you want to look for a different kind of restaurant. The chicken katsu has been my regular order up until a couple of weeks ago, when I tried the pork chops katsu: the breading is nice and crispy, the pork chops incredibly moist and thick and delicious. We recently tried the lumpia basket appetizer, which comes with a sweet/spicy dipping sauce—wonderful! My husband's favorite is the Loco Moco, scoops of white rice covered with hamburger patties and gravy and topped with a fried egg. The desserts on offer are basically cake with different fillings. The white cake with fruit-flavored filling is nothing special, but the chocolate cake with chantilly cream filling and frosting is heavenly! They seem to run out of this quickly (not a surprise that it's popular!), so if you go on a weekend, go early. That would also help with the seating. Recently Bobby's moved to Lynnwood in the Lake Serene area at 14626 Hwy 99, Suite 101 (in a small red-brick strip mall); note that the address and picture here on Trip Advisor are outdated, showing the pre-April 2013 storefront and address. Parking at the new location is ample; their new space is quite a bit bigger and they now have seating available while you wait for a table. Prices are on the low side of average; entree with mac salad and rice is about $8-13 depending on what you get. Desserts are around $4 but the size is generous. The waitstaff are friendly and are pretty good about checking back to see how the food is, keep drinks refilled, etc.; possibly a bit less so at busy times on weekends or when they have large parties in the banquet room. The booths are, thankfully, not ones you have to squeeze into so tightly that you can hardly breathe. And they are long enough to comfortably seat 6, so family groups can be easily accommodated. (There is also some table/chair seating.) Their website has the new address and shows their menu. Again, don't come here expecting a gourmet experience or a new-age fusion menu. This is Hawaiian "down home" cooking, and the staff at Bobby's definitely know what they are doing!

data.title: Spam I Am
data.text: This large, noisy, family friendly spot serves traditional Hawaiian food to the masses. It's appeal (which pretty much escapes me) seems to be that it is inexpensive so you can bring the whole family and not break the bank. Kids can even get hambergers or hot dogs if they like, while parents can have a beer and more traditional Hawaiian fare. It is noisy so no one seems to care if their kid is screaming because there are a lot of other screaming kids as well. No one seems to care that their kids are smearing their food on the table or dropping it on the floor because, again, this seems to be an acceptable norm. I think that if you don't have kids with you, or if you are not somewhat drunk, it is not the place for you. I also think that it is not the place for you if you are looking for good Hawaiian food- this is more like an Hawaiian McDonald's. It is really fast food with slow service.

data.title: Not quite what I was expecting!!
data.text: Food wasn't quite what I expected.  Not good and way overpriced!!  This thing is making me put 100 characters or more, otherwise it won't save.  How utterly ridiculous.  I specified the problem and yet it wasn't elaboration!!  Ridic!!!!!

data.title: Love Hawaiian Food.  This ain't it.
data.text: Having lived in Hawaiian for a long time I found this place didn't really have it & after seeing it on DINERS DRIVE-INS & DIVE I was shocked but they didn't seem to have their usual compliments about the food either.

data.title: Hawaiian Plates like back home
data.text: If you happen to be up North of Seattle, and develop a desire for a good Hawaiian plate, this is the place to go. Or, if you can't make it to Hawaii yet, but wish to experience some of the well-known "local" flavor, make your way up to Everett to Bobby's. Be aware, this is not your "let's dress-up, put on your best outfit, let's go out to fine dining tonight" place to eat. It is located down at the bottom of Hewitt Avenue in Everett, near the waterfront. What it does remind me of is being back home in the Islands, going out for "plate lunch", which can be anytime between noon & late at night when in Hawaii. The seating is basic, the bar comfortable, and the food is "onolicious", as we say back home. Favorites are the Hawaiian plate (bring a BIG appetite!) and Bobby's famous Kal-Bi ribs, a marinated thin-cut short rib that is really good, or as we say back home, "broke-da-mouth"!  If you just feel like fillig up on some real good eats, give Bobby's a shot.

data.title: DD&D, but I don't get the hype.
data.text: Middle of the road Hawaiian fare, I've tried to catch the hype but am not catching it.

data.title: What a find!
data.text: This restaurant is a real gem... good food, authentic flavors and just plain fun!

data.title: Meh
data.text: Food was ok.  Home made gummi bears were great.  Service was very friendly.  Don't waste your time if it means going out of your way.

data.title: Lau Lau Pork Curiosity
data.text:
I had driven by this place on Aurora so many times and thought I should stop there. Especially since Guy F. visited the main restaurant on Hewitt. I took my co-workers as a farewell dinner (moving on to another job) and wanted to thank them for being such a great team.

Ordered several app's, entrees and desserts which were shared among the 5 of us. 

I think what struck me most was the lack of seasoning. Especially with the Lau Lau Pork. A little salt would have done wonders.

I love food and I must confess that this stop dissapointed on so many levels. 

I must visit the main campus to see if it measures up

data.title: Good to try.
data.text:
We watch Diner Drive Inns and Dives and anytime we go to an area we check the website to see if the show has been anywhere close to where we are going to be.  

We were in the area to shop at the Seattle Premium Outlets and we wanted to try this place out.  

Got to the restaurant about 7:00pm and the place was not very busy (1 other table of 6 people).  We were acknowledge right away and seated.  The waitress was extremely friendly and prompt.  

After looking at the show in the morning we had a sense of what was ordered and were going to order that, but after inquiring about the food we changed to something that she recommended.  

We have three kids (11, 9, 7) so we decided to order from the platter section (like in a Chinese restaurant) instead of the individual meal section, so that the kids would be able to finish their food as she said that the portions were large.  

We had the Kalua Pig (pulled pork) and Mochi chicken (chicken nuggets), with steamed rice and macaroni salad.  Price was around $40.00 including tip.  

We enjoyed the food, and were glad we were able to check off another place from the triple D list.  

Would we eat there again - no, we would want to try another Triple D place
Was the food good to eat - Yes.  
Was the food greasier than we expected - yes - but never have been to Hawaii, so is that the way it is?

data.title: Pretty uneventful lunch at Bobby's Hawaiian
data.text: I ordered the BBQ chicken and it was your standard grilled chicken with a sugary marinade.  Served with white rice and a macaroni salad that had way too much mayo in it so I left that behind.  I think I will try the pork next time but overall not a place that I would hurry back to.

data.title: Reminded Me Of Hawaii
data.text: We choose to go to this restaurant as I'm a fan of Diners, Drive-In, and Dives show from the Food Network.  When we got there, we were hesitant to go in as the outside is not much to look at and the surrounding establishments were somewhat suspect.  However, upon opening the door to the restaurant I got a wave of smell that reminded me of Hawaii.  I agree with other reviewers that the decor is nothing special but then again I'm not looking for a fine dining experience.  The restaurant was clean and busy and there was only one very hard working waitress.  It took us a while to get our food but the wait was worth it.  We ordered the kalua plate, mixed plate where we choose two meats (chicken and beef) and a large bowl of saimin.  We loved the food and it was great value.  My two young boys enjoyed the meal as well.  We would definitely go back again when we're in Everett.
